title: Alumna Kelsie Whitmore to be first woman to play in MLB | Titan - The Digital Magazine of Cal State Fullerton
body: Some page features may require javascript to run.Skip to Content (Press Enter)A Titan Takes the FieldAlumna Kelsie Whitmore knew there would be a first woman to play Major League Baseball. Sheâs on the road to achieving that milestone.By Taylor Arrey / Photos By Matt GushKelsie Whitmore remembers rainy days. With water dancing on windows and wind howling in the distance, she and her younger brother would create a makeshift baseball diamond in her childhood living room.Even when the game was little more than pillow bases and a handful of wiffle balls, Whitmore knew one thing for certain.Rain or shine, she was always going to play baseball.First Season as a FerryhawkWhitmore â20, â22 (B.S. kinesiology, M.S. instructional design and technology), a Cal State Fullerton alumna and professional baseball player, took the field in April 2022 as an outfielder and pitcher for the Staten Island FerryHawks. She made history as the first woman to play in the Atlantic League, one of four Major League Baseball partner leagues.Cal State Fullerton alumna Kelsie Whitmore took the field as an outfielder and pitcher for the Staten Island FerryHawks in April 2022, making history as the first woman to play in a Major League Baseball partner league.âI always knew that there was going to be a girl one day, and I thought, if there is one, I want to be that girl who makes it,â says the former Titan softball player.After signing with the FerryHawks, Whitmoreâs name appeared on jerseys and in national headlines. Sharing her story with publications like the MLB Network, Sports Illustrated and The Athletic, Whitmoreâs fan base grew tremendously. It wasnât long before she was autographing baseballs and interacting with fans in the stands.Kelsie Whitmore (left) said she enjoys interacting with fans and showing young girls that they belong in baseball.On the field, the two-way sensation played 86 innings in the outfield and pitched 10.1 innings.âBeing able to play with and against former major leaguers like Rusney Castillo from the Red Sox and Julio Teheran from the Tigers â that atmosphere â itâs everything you work for and dream of,â shares Whitmore.In the offseason, Whitmore hits the gym and works on her mechanics, hoping to take her game to the next level.âWhen Iâm back on the field this season, I want to come back and have people say, âThis girl worked hard and came back better,ââ says Whitmore.I never saw myself doing anything else.- Kelsie Whitmore â20, â22Field of DreamsKelsie Whitmore â20, â22 (B.S. kinesiology, M.S. instructional design and technology)Before she was a FerryHawk, Whitmore found a supportive community of teammates and coaches at Cal State Fullertonâs Anderson Family Field.âCollege was the time when I really opened up as a person and as a player,â shares Whitmore. âFrom the start of my college career to when I became a senior, my relationship with my coaches continued to grow. Their support helped me open up about my hopes for the future.âSoftball head coach Kelly Ford met Whitmore at a recruiting camp in 2017 and was impressed by her drive, athleticism and shining potential.âI remember her spending time with our baseball staff,â says Ford. âAfter that, there wasnât a year that went by that she didnât participate in a camp, a USA Baseball event or training.âFrom late nights in the bullpen to networking events, Whitmore seized every opportunity for professional development at CSUF and grew as a leader and teammate.âKelsie welcomed all the freshmen with open arms and guided us,â says Alyssa Hernandez, former Titan softball player and Whitmoreâs best friend. âShe always put others before herself and set a good example of what it means to be a Titan softball player.âFord adds that Whitmore left behind a legacy of strength, kindness and wisdom when she graduated â a legacy that still exists today.âKelsie changed the standard of how the Titans take the field,â says Ford. âHer teammates and coaches had the utmost respect for her, and she will forever be a part of Titan softball.âBaseball Hits HomeWhitmore started playing catch with her dad when she was 6 years old. As an energetic kid who loved being outdoors, her childhood revolved around sports. She played soccer, volleyball, golf, and participated in high school track and field, but her heart always went back to baseball.âI never saw myself doing anything else,â says Whitmore.Kelsie Whitmore began playing baseball when she was 6 years old.Before joining the USA Baseball team in 2014, she played Little League and was on Temecula Valley High Schoolâs varsity team. She also played travel baseball, where her dad doubled as her coach for several seasons. With each step, Whitmore knew that she wanted to be a professional baseball player, but she didnât always say it out loud.âPeople would ask me what I wanted to be when I grew up, and I knew. I knew exactly what I wanted to do, but I stopped telling people because I got shut down a lot,â says Whitmore.It took some time, but in the face of criticism, she learned to be unapologetic about her goals by surrounding herself with positivity and a healthy support system.Her dream is to sign an MLB contract with the San Diego Padres â the team that she grew up watching.Changing the GameToday, when Whitmore takes the field, she does so with a quiet confidence that eclipses the challenges she has faced along the way.âI compared myself to men because they were my competition. I never had a body like them. I never had the build, the strength, the speed or the power, and I was so envious of that,â shares Whitmore. âI overworked myself trying to outperform the competition. What helped me overcome that was learning to love what I was given and who I was.âOutfielder Evelyn Sablan (right) and alumna Kelsie Whitmore (left) became friends while playing on the Titan softball team.Peyton Toto, a third-year Titan infielder, says that Whitmoreâs vulnerability is reshaping the game for young athletes.âHer story has inspired a lot of girls to chase their goals. Itâs rare that a person would keep going after being told so many times, âWomen donât play baseballâ or âItâs a menâs sport,ââ says Toto.Despite these challenges, Whitmore says sheâs proud to be opening doors for future female MLB baseball players.âWhat sheâs doing for young people, we are going to reap the benefits as a sports community for decades to come,â says Ford. âAs far as breaking the glass ceiling, her journey has only just begun.â Support Titan Softball:give.fullerton.edu/softballMore StoriesOnce a Titan, Always a TitanThe Secretâs in the Hot SauceChloe the Engineer Stomps Out StereotypesRaising $270 Million: A Titan Success StoryPresidentâs MessageThis site is maintained by Division of University AdvancementTo report problems or to comment about this site, please contact strategiccomm@fullerton.eduÂ Â |Â Â Privacy PolicyÂ© California State University, Fullerton.
